For the 3D CBCT track, the winning approach boosted the Instance Dice score by 61 percentage points. This challenge confirms the substantial benefit of SSL for complex, instance-level medical image segmentation tasks where labeled data is scarce. The most effective approaches consistently leveraged hybrid semi-supervised frameworks that combined knowledge from foundational models like SAM with multi-stage, coarse-to-fine refinement pipelines. Both the challenge dataset and the participants' submitted code have been made publicly available on GitHub (https://github.com/ricoleehduu/STS-Challenge-2024), ensuring transparency and reproducibility.

AI.tldr: The paper presents the STS 2024 Challenge results, showing semi-supervised learning significantly outperforms fully-supervised baselines for tooth segmentation in dental imaging when labeled data is scarce.
AI.motivation: Manual instance-level annotation for dental images (OPGs and CBCT) is labor-intensive, creating a data scarcity problem for automated tooth segmentation that needs to be addressed.
AI.method: Organized the 2nd Semi-supervised Teeth Segmentation Challenge at MICCAI 2024 with a large-scale dataset (90k+ images), evaluated top SSL submissions from 114 OPG and 106 CBCT teams, focusing on open-source, deep learning-based SSL methods.
AI.result: SSL methods achieved dramatic improvements: top OPG method improved Instance Affinity score by 44+ percentage points, top CBCT method boosted Instance Dice score by 61 percentage points over fully-supervised baseline.
AI.conclusion: SSL provides substantial benefits for complex instance-level medical image segmentation with scarce labeled data, with best approaches using hybrid frameworks combining foundational models like SAM with multi-stage refinement pipelines.

title: Geodiffussr: Generative Terrain Texturing with Elevation Fidelity
summary: Large-scale terrain generation remains a labor-intensive task in computer graphics. We introduce Geodiffussr, a flow-matching pipeline that synthesizes text-guided texture maps while strictly adhering to a supplied Digital Elevation Map (DEM). The core mechanism is multi-scale content aggregation (MCA): DEM features from a pretrained encoder are injected into UNet blocks at multiple resolutions to enforce global-to-local elevation consistency. Compared with a non-MCA baseline, MCA markedly improves visual fidelity and strengthens height-appearance coupling (FID $\downarrow$ 49.16%, LPIPS $\downarrow$ 32.33%, $Δ$dCor $\downarrow$ to 0.0016). To train and evaluate Geodiffussr, we assemble a globally distributed, biome- and climate-stratified corpus of triplets pairing SRTM-derived DEMs with Sentinel-2 imagery and vision-grounded natural-language captions that describe visible land cover. We position Geodiffussr as a strong baseline and step toward controllable 2.5D landscape generation for coarse-scale ideation and previz, complementary to physically based terrain and ecosystem simulators.

AI.tldr: Geodiffussr is a flow-matching pipeline that generates text-guided terrain textures while strictly following input elevation maps, using multi-scale content aggregation to enforce elevation-consistency.
AI.motivation: Large-scale terrain generation is labor-intensive in computer graphics. There's a need for controllable 2.5D landscape generation that can follow elevation constraints while being guided by natural language descriptions.
AI.method: Flow-matching pipeline with multi-scale content aggregation (MCA): DEM features from a pretrained encoder are injected into UNet blocks at multiple resolutions to enforce global-to-local elevation consistency. Trained on a global dataset of DEMs paired with Sentinel-2 imagery and natural language captions.
AI.result: MCA significantly improves visual fidelity and height-appearance coupling: FID ↓ 49.16%, LPIPS ↓ 32.33%, ΔdCor ↓ to 0.0016 compared to non-MCA baseline. Creates a strong baseline for controllable 2.5D landscape generation.
AI.conclusion: Geodiffussr provides a step toward controllable 2.5D landscape generation for coarse-scale ideation and previz, complementary to physically based terrain and ecosystem simulators.

title: DiskChunGS: Large-Scale 3D Gaussian SLAM Through Chunk-Based Memory Management
summary: Recent advances in 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) have demonstrated impressive results for novel view synthesis with real-time rendering capabilities. However, integrating 3DGS with SLAM systems faces a fundamental scalability limitation: methods are constrained by GPU memory capacity, restricting reconstruction to small-scale environments. We present DiskChunGS, a scalable 3DGS SLAM system that overcomes this bottleneck through an out-of-core approach that partitions scenes into spatial chunks and maintains only active regions in GPU memory while storing inactive areas on disk. Our architecture integrates seamlessly with existing SLAM frameworks for pose estimation and loop closure, enabling globally consistent reconstruction at scale. We validate DiskChunGS on indoor scenes (Replica, TUM-RGBD), urban driving scenarios (KITTI), and resource-constrained Nvidia Jetson platforms. Our method uniquely completes all 11 KITTI sequences without memory failures while achieving superior visual quality, demonstrating that algorithmic innovation can overcome the memory constraints that have limited previous 3DGS SLAM methods.

AI.tldr: DiskChunGS is a scalable 3D Gaussian Splatting SLAM system that uses spatial chunking and out-of-core memory management to overcome GPU memory limitations, enabling large-scale reconstruction across diverse environments.
AI.motivation: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has shown impressive real-time rendering for novel view synthesis, but integrating it with SLAM systems faces fundamental scalability limitations due to GPU memory constraints, restricting reconstruction to small-scale environments.
AI.method: DiskChunGS uses an out-of-core approach that partitions scenes into spatial chunks, maintaining only active regions in GPU memory while storing inactive areas on disk. It integrates with existing SLAM frameworks for pose estimation and loop closure.
AI.result: Validated on indoor scenes (Replica, TUM-RGBD), urban driving scenarios (KITTI), and resource-constrained Nvidia Jetson platforms. Uniquely completes all 11 KITTI sequences without memory failures while achieving superior visual quality.
AI.conclusion: DiskChunGS demonstrates that algorithmic innovation can overcome the memory constraints that have limited previous 3DGS SLAM methods, enabling globally consistent reconstruction at scale across diverse environments.

title: Obstruction reasoning for robotic grasping
summary: Successful robotic grasping in cluttered environments not only requires a model to visually ground a target object but also to reason about obstructions that must be cleared beforehand. While current vision-language embodied reasoning models show emergent spatial understanding, they remain limited in terms of obstruction reasoning and accessibility planning. To bridge this gap, we present UNOGrasp, a learning-based vision-language model capable of performing visually-grounded obstruction reasoning to infer the sequence of actions needed to unobstruct the path and grasp the target object. We devise a novel multi-step reasoning process based on obstruction paths originated by the target object. We anchor each reasoning step with obstruction-aware visual cues to incentivize reasoning capability. UNOGrasp combines supervised and reinforcement finetuning through verifiable reasoning rewards. Moreover, we construct UNOBench, a large-scale dataset for both training and benchmarking, based on MetaGraspNetV2, with over 100k obstruction paths annotated by humans with obstruction ratios, contact points, and natural-language instructions. Extensive experiments and real-robot evaluations show that UNOGrasp significantly improves obstruction reasoning and grasp success across both synthetic and real-world environments, outperforming generalist and proprietary alternatives. Project website: https://tev-fbk.github.io/UnoGrasp/.

AI.tldr: UNOGrasp is a vision-language model for robotic grasping that performs obstruction reasoning to plan actions for clearing obstructions before grasping target objects in cluttered environments.
AI.motivation: Current vision-language embodied reasoning models show emergent spatial understanding but remain limited in obstruction reasoning and accessibility planning for robotic grasping in cluttered environments.
AI.method: UNOGrasp uses a novel multi-step reasoning process based on obstruction paths from target objects, anchored with obstruction-aware visual cues. It combines supervised and reinforcement finetuning with verifiable reasoning rewards, trained on UNOBench dataset with over 100k human-annotated obstruction paths.
AI.result: UNOGrasp significantly improves obstruction reasoning and grasp success across synthetic and real-world environments, outperforming generalist and proprietary alternatives in extensive experiments and real-robot evaluations.
AI.conclusion: UNOGrasp bridges the gap in obstruction reasoning for robotic grasping, demonstrating effective visually-grounded reasoning for clearing obstructions before grasping in cluttered environments.

title: Machine Learning for Scientific Visualization: Ensemble Data Analysis
summary: Scientific simulations and experimental measurements produce vast amounts of spatio-temporal data, yet extracting meaningful insights remains challenging due to high dimensionality, complex structures, and missing information. Traditional analysis methods often struggle with these issues, motivating the need for more robust, data-driven approaches. This dissertation explores deep learning methodologies to improve the analysis and visualization of spatio-temporal scientific ensembles, focusing on dimensionality reduction, flow estimation, and temporal interpolation. First, we address high-dimensional data representation through autoencoder-based dimensionality reduction for scientific ensembles. We evaluate the stability of projection metrics under partial labeling and introduce a Pareto-efficient selection strategy to identify optimal autoencoder variants, ensuring expressive and reliable low-dimensional embeddings. Next, we present FLINT, a deep learning model for high-quality flow estimation and temporal interpolation in both flow-supervised and flow-unsupervised settings. FLINT reconstructs missing velocity fields and generates high-fidelity temporal interpolants for scalar fields across 2D+time and 3D+time ensembles without domain-specific assumptions or extensive finetuning. To further improve adaptability and generalization, we introduce HyperFLINT, a hypernetwork-based approach that conditions on simulation parameters to estimate flow fields and interpolate scalar data. This parameter-aware adaptation yields more accurate reconstructions across diverse scientific domains, even with sparse or incomplete data. Overall, this dissertation advances deep learning techniques for scientific visualization, providing scalable, adaptable, and high-quality solutions for interpreting complex spatio-temporal ensembles.

AI.tldr: This dissertation develops deep learning methods for analyzing spatio-temporal scientific ensembles, focusing on autoencoder-based dimensionality reduction, FLINT for flow estimation/interpolation, and HyperFLINT for parameter-aware adaptation.
AI.motivation: Scientific simulations and experiments produce vast spatio-temporal data that is high-dimensional, complex, and often incomplete. Traditional analysis methods struggle with these challenges, creating a need for robust, data-driven approaches to extract meaningful insights.
AI.method: Three main approaches: 1) Autoencoder-based dimensionality reduction with Pareto-efficient selection for optimal embeddings; 2) FLINT model for flow estimation and temporal interpolation in both supervised and unsupervised settings; 3) HyperFLINT using hypernetworks conditioned on simulation parameters for improved adaptability.
AI.result: Developed scalable deep learning solutions that provide expressive low-dimensional embeddings, reconstruct missing velocity fields, generate high-fidelity temporal interpolants for scalar fields, and achieve accurate reconstructions across diverse scientific domains even with sparse data.
AI.conclusion: The dissertation advances deep learning techniques for scientific visualization by providing scalable, adaptable, and high-quality solutions for interpreting complex spatio-temporal ensembles, addressing key challenges in dimensionality reduction, flow estimation, and temporal interpolation.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Thermophysical Property Retrieval
summary: Inverse heat problems refer to the estimation of material thermophysical properties given observed or known heat diffusion behaviour. Inverse heat problems have wide-ranging uses, but a critical application lies in quantifying how building facade renovation reduces thermal transmittance, a key determinant of building energy efficiency. However, solving inverse heat problems with non-invasive data collected in situ is error-prone due to environmental variability or deviations from theoretically assumed conditions. Hence, current methods for measuring thermal conductivity are either invasive, require lengthy observation periods, or are sensitive to environmental and experimental conditions. Here, we present a PINN-based iterative framework to estimate the thermal conductivity k of a wall from a set of thermographs; our framework alternates between estimating the forward heat problem with a PINN for a fixed k, and optimizing k by comparing the thermographs and surface temperatures predicted by the PINN, repeating until the estimated k's convergence. Using both environmental data captured by a weather station and data generated from Finite-Volume-Method software simulations, we accurately predict k across different environmental conditions and data collection sampling times, given the temperature profile of the wall at dawn is close to steady state. Although violating the steady-state assumption impacts the accuracy of k's estimation, we show that our proposed framework still only exhibits a maximum MAE of 4.0851. Our work demonstrates the potential of PINN-based methods for reliable estimation of material properties in situ and under realistic conditions, without lengthy measurement campaigns. Given the lack of research on using machine learning, and more specifically on PINNs, for solving in-situ inverse problems, we expect our work to be a starting point for more research on the topic.

AI.tldr: PINN-based iterative framework for estimating wall thermal conductivity from thermographs, achieving accurate results under realistic conditions without lengthy measurements.
AI.motivation: Current methods for measuring thermal conductivity are invasive, time-consuming, or sensitive to environmental conditions. There's a need for reliable non-invasive in-situ estimation of material properties for building energy efficiency assessment.
AI.method: Iterative PINN framework that alternates between: 1) solving forward heat problem with PINN for fixed thermal conductivity k, and 2) optimizing k by comparing actual thermographs with PINN-predicted surface temperatures, repeating until convergence.
AI.result: Accurate thermal conductivity prediction across different environmental conditions and sampling times when dawn temperature profile is near steady state. Even when steady-state assumption is violated, maximum MAE is only 4.0851.
AI.conclusion: PINN-based methods show strong potential for reliable in-situ material property estimation under realistic conditions without lengthy measurement campaigns, serving as a starting point for more research on ML/PINN approaches to inverse problems.
